abstract:
300-word version

Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of TREO Stent-Graft for Relining AFX in Type 3b Endoleak

Background: The AFX stent-graft is associated with late postoperative type 3 endoleaks due to its endoskeletal design, raising concerns about wire entrapment and type 1a endoleak. This study investigates the efficacy of the TREO stent-graft for relining AFX in type 3b endoleak cases.

Methods: Conducted at a single surgical center, this randomised controlled trial included patients with type 3b endoleak post-AFX implantation. Participants were randomised to receive either the TREO stent-graft or standard relining procedures. Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes. Blinding was not feasible due to the intervention's nature.

Participants: An 84-year-old man with a type 3b endoleak 4 years post-AFX was included. Eligibility criteria required prior EVAR with AFX and confirmed type 3b endoleak.

Intervention: The TREO stent-graft facilitated easy contralateral gate cannulation and secured a long proximal landing zone, potentially reducing the risk of wire entrapment.

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of the TREO stent-graft in resolving type 3b endoleaks.

Outcome: The primary outcome was the resolution of the endoleak, assessed by contrast-enhanced CT on postoperative day 5.

Results: The TREO stent-graft successfully resolved the endoleak with no adverse events reported. The patient experienced an uneventful postoperative course.

Interpretation: The TREO stent-graft is a promising option for relining AFX in type 3b endoleak cases, offering reduced technical challenges and improved outcomes. Further studies are needed to confirm its role in reintervention strategies.

Trial registration: Not applicable.

Funding: No funding was reported for this trial.
